subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - (Early) 13th December 2019: US and China agree on phase one deal whilst UK Conservatives win majority
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • REAR VIEW: US China agree on Phase One deal, mixed reception; UK sees Tory majority; retail sales miss expectations, revised higher
  • NOTICE: Desk will close at 18:00GMT/12:00CST on Friday after the Baker Hughes release – subject to market conditions. 

US MARKET WRAP 13th December 2019: US and China agree on phase one deal whilst UK Conservatives win majority

* MARKET WRAP: Following reports yesterday that an agreement for a phase one deal had been reached, the Chinese side announced that a deal had been agreed which initially saw equities extend to on its all-time highs after the UK election saw a Conservative majority, thus removing the uncertainty for the next phase of Brexit. Prior to the announcement US President Trump dismissed reports in the WSJ yesterday, particularly on Tariffs, which stated as part of the deal the US would cut existing tariffs by up to 50%, plus cancelling the announcement of the phase one deal saw a broad risk on move across asset classes which saw USDCNH rise back above the 7.00 handle amid a broad a risk off move. However, on the official announcement risk on was observed as participants were wary whether a deal had been reached or not. The news saw WTI (F0) breach USD 60/bbl to the upside, whilst Brent hit highs of USD 65.80, whilst USDCNH fell back beneath the 7.00 figure briefly. US Yields spiked higher to just shy of 1.91%. However, the details of the deal failed to woo participants as not all tariffs had been removed, which has been an ongoing request from the Chinese for both sides to see any true progress. The Chinese did note that the cancelling of Dec. 15th tariffs from both sides and a rollback of tariffs to 7.5% from 15%, was welcomed. Also, there had been no formal agreement on US agricultural goods, where details are set to be revealed at a later stage. In terms of the physical signing, they are currently discussing where, when and who will be signing off the deal. The aftermath of the announcement saw a reversal of the initial risk on reaction which saw the crude complex return to pre-announcement levels, USDCNH back above the key 7.00 figure, yields sent to session lows and a paring of gains in equities. Over in the UK after the Conservative party won a majority of 80 seats, GBP skyrocketed which saw Cable initially breach 1.35 to the upside from ~1.3150, whilst also providing a boost to FTSE and a gap lower to gilts.

* US/CHINA: As the Chinese address got under way a risk-on move was seen across major assets - equity bourses were bid, the greenback firmed and havens were offered - with the Chinese Vice Commerce Minister saying negotiations achieved major progress and agreed on the context of the deal. The Minister said the US will follow through on its promise to cancel tariffs on a phased basis and that China would increase its imports from China, namely, energy, agricultural, pharmaceutical products and financial services; note that no agreement has been made on the agricultural purchases figure yet, seemingly as a Chinese official dodged the question, although US President Trump announced the Chinse are already purchasing the goods, and he believed China will hit USD 50bln worth of purchases. Furthermore, It was also announced that China would cancel (note not delay) its planned tariffs to take effect on Sunday, where both sides agree not to impose the Sunday tariffs, note, nothing was mentioned on previous rollbacks or any 'goodwill' or 'token' style reductions from either side. In regard to the signing of the deal, China said the details are still being worked on, however USTR Lighthizer announced it would take place in the first week of January in Washington, although a presidential signing is not expected. US President Trump announced after that the US would be maintaining the existing 25% tariffs, which currently covers USD 250bln worth of Chinese imports, whilst it would be cutting the remaining tariffs, which currently stands at 15% on USD 125bln of Chinese imports, to 7.5%. However, on Trump's announcements, perhaps due to him not cutting the 25% tariffs, the initial risk-on move did pare back somewhat.

* UK ELECTION: The Conservative Party won an unexpectedly large majority at the General Elections (majority of 80 seats). The outcome unblocks the parliamentary channels and given that Johnson claimed all Conservative candidates backed his divorce deal, the market expects lawmakers to pass the Withdrawal Agreement by the end of the year – possibly as early as next week. The Europeans are also expecting the Tories to swiftly pass the divorce deal, and a diplomatic source on Friday said that EU leaders have agreed to go ahead with trade talks after the ratification and effective implementation of the exit deal. Taking a more medium-term view, there are a couple of factors to keep in mind: 1) many have suggested that negotiating a free trade agreement with the EU by the end of 2020, while made easier by a large majority, is a tall ask, even though the UK is currently aligned with the bloc in many areas; the UK must, by the end of June 2020, decide on whether it wants to extend the transition period (which runs through to the end of 2020), and many expect that the UK will have to extend, or face a potential hard exit on WTO terms at the end of the year; 2) some analysts have suggested that the magnitude of the Tory victory leaves the government with much optionality regarding fiscal stimulus, with some suggesting that there is less of a need to flood the economy with largesse (and thus maintaining a prudent fiscal policy stance) given the size of the majority; clarity on this theme will only be known around the Budget in February – the course for UK rates will likely be a function of BOE and the fiscal equation in the coming months, some desks have suggested. 3) Given that the Scots overwhelming voted for hard line nationalists, the SNP, which is set to renew the push for independence; additionally, the DUP (which was previously supporting the government) has not fared particularly well in Ireland, with Irish Sinn Fein taking leader Dodds’ seat; the unionists now have now also lost their majority in Northern Ireland for the first time, hinting that a more nationalist line might be seen out of Ireland too.

* US NOVEMBER RETAIL SALES: It was a disappointing report, with headline retail sales coming in at +0.2% M/M, short of the consensus +0.5%. The core measure was up +0.1% M/M missing the +0.4% forecast, while the control group measure printed +0.1% short of the +0.3% forecast. The prior readings were revised up slightly, but the control group prior was revised down. “The spike in sales captured by the Redbook survey in the week of Thanksgiving pointed to better numbers, but the earlier part of the month might have suffered from the after-effects of strong tariff front-running spending in August and September,” Pantheon Macroeconomics wrote, “The fourth quarter as a whole could yet be rescued by a strong December, though, and/or the November data could be revised up substantially,” PM notes, observing that the numbers are volatile, and forecasting holiday season sales with confidence has been made very difficult by the structural shift in the timing of peak spending, towards Thanksgiving weekend and Cyber Monday; the latter this year fell in December. “Right now, though, even a hefty 1% jump in control sales in December would complete a mere 2.3% annualized increase in Q4, down from 6.0% in Q3 and 7.9% in Q2,” PM says, adding “those numbers could never be sustained, but they made it easy to believe the story of the invincible consumer – that narrative now looks harder to sustain, and if capex and exports are anything like as weak as surveys suggest, the softening in consumption will make it hard for Q4 GDP growth to breach 2%.”

* EARNINGS: Adobe (ADBE) surged after a strong Q4 report, particularly Net new ARR exceeding (recently updated) expectations, whilst affirming guidance. Broadcom (AVGO) dipped lower after its guidance, including the Symantec (SYMC) acquisition, was lacklustre, particularly in its wireless business. Costco (COST) traded subdued, although the quarter was mainly decent, the revenue was slightly light, with desks noting its outperformance YTD. Oracle (ORCL) also underperformed on a light revenue print.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) caught a relief rally as it narrowly avoided the December 15th tariffs. CenterPoint (CNP) was bid on reports it was in settlement talks in its rates lawsuit in Houston. Facebook (FB) extended its losses from Thursday amid the FTC looking to act against it over antitrust concerns. Financials (BKX, XLF) were hit on the flattening of the yield curve. Lululemon (LULU) opened lower due to large block trade below its market price. PPL Corp (PPL) was supported by its exposure to the UK after the Tory landslide election victory supporting the utilities sector. Sarepta Therapeutics (SRPT) spiked higher on an early FDA approval. Tapestry (TPR) was offered amid a key brand leader departure. Gilead (GILD) sold off on a Credit Suisse downgrade, whilst the bank supported Biogen (BIIB), upgrading it. HanesBrands (HBI) dipped on a BofAML downgrade.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: USD: The Dollar remains on track for net weekly losses, albeit with the DXY off worst levels within a 96.605-97.925 range and back above the 97.000 handle (just), and its demise really started after a dovish final FOMC policy meeting of the year. To recap, the Fed noted muted inflation and the SEP dot plots transposed no change in rates over 2020, while Chair Powell lifted the bar for any reversal of the mid-cycle insurance easing administered via three 25 bp cuts. Meanwhile, US data has been decidedly less frothy than last Friday’s stellar BLS report, but US-China trade developments very pivotal in terms of market moves and sentiment after President Trump revealed that a Phase 1 deal was in the offing and a late/delayed Beijing press briefing effectively confirmed the agreement. Of note, China stated that December 15 tariffs are now off the table and Trump announced a reciprocal removal of the levies pencilled in for this Sunday, but the former refused to be pinned down on the size of ag purchases that have been a major sticking point and the latter also left 25% on a previous Usd250 bn, while halving Usd120 bn to 7.5% from 15%.

GBP: In stark contrast to the Greenback’s travails, Sterling has had a stellar week even though best gains and euphoria have faded in the afterglow of the UK GE that saw the Conservative Party blitz main opposition Labour and PM Johnson given a working if not whopping 80 seat majority to deliver on his pledge to get Brexit done by January 31 next year. Cable has been as high as 1.3514 compared to 1.3053 when pre-vote polls predicted a much tighter result, while Eur/Gbp has seen peaks and troughs of 0.8508 and 0.8278.

CHF/EUR/TRY/RUB/BRL: All partly attuned to central bank policy meetings along with the wider fluctuations in risk sentiment of course. The Franc is ending the week broadly stronger even though the SNB underscored its determination to maintain NIRP and an active brief in terms of currency intervention, perhaps taking note of the fact that the Swiss cb did not raise its valuation of the Chf and set its inflation projections on a base case unchanged benchmark rate for the forecast horizon (out to 2022). Meanwhile, the Euro was whippy during ECB President Lagarde’s first post-policy meeting press conference and between 1.1199-1.1054 extremes on the week and is now around middle ground as she made a relative balanced statement, acknowledging encouraging data/surveys on the growth side vs still muted inflation and kept fairly tight-lipped on details when asked about the looming strategic review. Elsewhere, mostly dovish moves/guidance from the CBRT, CBR and BCB relative to expectations did not really dent the Lira, Rouble or Real, but a downturn in risk appetite after the aforementioned China and US statements on Phase One and tariffs did weigh on top of sanction and Russian missile angst in the case of the former.

NZD/CAD/AUD: The non-US Dollars have all endured volatile weeks on breaking trade headlines/developments, cross flows and technical impulses, with the Kiwi and Aussie dovetailing down under after the NZ Half Year Fiscal Update unveiled an extra Nzd12 bn for infrastructure projects and the budget gap widened. However, the Loonie managed to overcome more disappointing Canadian data with the aid of a USMCA accord that also boosted the Mexican Peso (predictably).

SEK/NOK: In keeping with the above, positions have chopped and changed in Scandinavia ahead of next week’s last 2019 Riksbank and Norges Bank meetings and following mixed Swedish data in the form of CPI and jobs, while Norwegian inflation prints were bang in line with expectations, but regional survey pretty downbeat overall.

EM: Lots of action in the Yuan on all the US-China trade/tariff news and some worrying trade data, with Usd/Cnh swinging from a high just over 7.0400 to lows of circa 6.9230 and now back on the psychological 7.0000 level as initial Phase 1 positivity fizzled out (buy rumour/sell fact perhaps?). Similarly, the Rand see-sawed between 14.8670-3735 or so amidst weak SA data vs a supportive SARB Quarterly Bulletin on balance, but was mostly directed by Eskom load-shedding that hit record levels before improving.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News: 13th December 2019
content:
13th December 2019

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has acquired the UK startup, Spectral Edge, for an undisclosed figure, where the Co augments colours in photos by simultaneously taking infrared and standard photos and blending the two.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) has lost an order after Qantas selected Airbus (AIR FP, EADSY) to fly its ultra-long-haul routes; decision on whether these routes will be utilised will be announced in March 2020. Elsewhere, American Airlines Group (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) has removed 737 MAX jets from its schedule through till April 6th.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) - FDA has approved XELJANZ XR extended release 11 mg and 22 mg tablets for treatment of ulcerative colitis.

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • The result of the UK election exit poll overwhelmingly pointed towards a Conservative majority with a total of 368 seats vs. Labour 191 - Conservatives managed to cross the 326-seat threshold just before 0500GMT
  • GBP immediately saw strength following the election exit poll with GBP/USD eclipsing 1.3500 to the upside from mid-1.3100 area
  • China and the US have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the tariffs that were due to come into effect on December 15th according to sources, announcement expected today
  • Further sources noted that there will be a small reduction in tariffs on some Chinese goods as a gesture of good will, while Phase Two of the negotiations will begin after 2020 elections
  • European bourses are higher across the board with FTSE 100 outperforming as GBP drifts off highs
  • In FX, DXY gave up the 97.000 level on GBP strength, EUR/GBP fell to its weakest since mid-2016
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Import/Export Prices & Retail Sales, Fed’s Williams

UK ELECTION

The result of the UK election exit poll overwhelmingly pointed towards a Conservative majority with a total of 368 seats vs. Labour 191, presenting the Conservatives with an expected majority of 86. Even with a margin of error of around 15 seats, this stood the Conservatives well clear of the 326 required to govern. In an immediate reaction GBP saw strength across the board with GBP/USD jumping from around the mid 1.31 level to 1.3514; the highest since June 2018. Support for GBP stemmed from the implications for the Brexit process given that Johnson stated that all Conservative candidates had agreed to approve the withdrawal agreement in the HoC, the passage of the bill is all but certain (date tbc).

As the results of individual seats were announced, the findings of the exit poll appeared to be vindicated with Labour broadly either seeing their majority in key seats dwindle or change hands with the Conservatives. As such, the market reaction during the announcement was relatively limited with the Conservatives managing to cross the 326-seat threshold just before 0500GMT; the final result and extent of the majority is yet to be confirmed.

US President Trump congratulates UK PM Johnson on winning the UK election, adds that UK and US are now free for a "massive new trade deal" post-Brexit, "This has the potential to be far bigger and more lucrative than any deal that could be made with EU". (Twitter)

Senior German Lawmaker notes that the PM Johnson's victory Brexit is now inevitable, goal now is to keep UK-EU relations as close as is possible. (Newswires)

What lies ahead? As we mentioned in our commentary, with the passage of the Withdrawal Agreement almost a given, focus will at some stage turn towards the transition period with the EU which is due to expire in December 2020. A decision on whether to extend this (end of December 2022 is the limit of any extension) is due at the end of June. However, Johnson has backed himself into a corner by stating he would not extend the transition period and therefore in theory, the possibility of a cliff-edge exit is still live. When this becomes the source of focus for the market is yet to be seen, however, the decision over whether to extend or not will likely be set for a much rougher ride than the passage of the WA. From a European perspective, BBC’s Adler has already reported that “Brussels does not believe an ambitious trade deal is possible to be negotiated and ratified by December next year as PM Johnson claims, with the only possibility in the short time said to be a quick and dirty free trade deal on EU terms”

TRADE

China and the US have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the tariffs that were due to come into effect on December 15th according to sources which added that China has agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020, while other source reports also stated the US will announce the trade deal today. (Newswires)

Fox Business' Lawrence tweeted that a source stated the December 15th tariffs will not go forward and there will be a small reduction in tariffs on some Chinese goods as a gesture of good will, while Phase Two of the negotiations will begin after 2020 elections.  Furthermore, the source said a signing ceremony will not happen with President Xi and there will be a rollout of the agreement by the White House Friday, while the Chinese have requested that the language of the never be made public. (Twitter)

China leaders are yet to accept the deal (referring to the 'big deal' US President Trump tweeted about) a number of issues: USD 50bln purchases is a hard target, other trade partners complaining at a reallocation who could challenge the WTO., CNBC's Yoon citing sources. (Twitter)

Though Beijing sees the benefit of an imminent deal, it still wants to ensure that China does't appear to have been pressured into making concessions, according to WSJ. (WSJ)

China's Foreign Ministry, regarding US trade talks, reiterates that China is committed to resolving issues but the deal needs to be mutually beneficial. (Newswires)

Certain US lawmakers urged US Secretary of State Pompeo and US Commerce Secretary Ross to sanction China related to its actions in Xinjiang, while there had also been separate comments from Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi that US actions have caused serious damage to the hard-won mutual trust between China and US. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

A broad heightened appetite for risk was seen overnight with the Asia-Pac majors bolstered and US equity futures extending on Wall St’s fresh record levels as markets reacted to reports that US and China have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the December 15th tariffs, while China is said to have agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020. In addition, focus was dominated by the UK election results in which PM Johnson’s Conservatives are on course for an overwhelming 86-seat majority according to exit polls. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.6%) were lifted with financials after banking regulator APRA advised ADIs it will delay finalizing consultation on implementation of product responsibility requirements until H1 next year but with hefty losses in gold miners restricting gains for the index, while the Japanese benchmark broke through the 24k milestone to print its highest since October 2018 with a somewhat disappointing Tankan survey doing little to contain the rally. Hang Seng (+2.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.8%) were also buoyed on the flurry of positive trade rhetoric as aside from the source reports of an agreement being reached in principle, there had also been optimistic comments from US President Trump regarding a trade deal and WSJ initially noted US negotiators offered to cut existing tariff rates by up to 50% although no official announcement has been made yet from either side. Finally, 10yr JGBs retraced some of the prior day’s losses which had been the by-product of the dramatically improved trade climate, with the rebound also helped by the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral weekly position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0156 vs. Exp. 7.0139 (Prev. 7.0253)

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Index (Q4) 0 vs. Exp. 2 (Prev. 5); lowest since March 2013. (Newswires) Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Outlook (Q4) 0 vs. Exp. 3 (Prev. 2) Japanese Tankan Large Non-Manufacturing Index (Q4) 20 vs. Exp. 16 (Prev. 21) Japanese Tankan Large All Industry Capex (Q4) 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.6%)

PBoC will conduct medium-term lending facility loan operation on Monday., according to reports. (Newswires)

Bundesbank: 2020 German GDP growth at 0.6% vs. Prev. 1.2%, 2021 at 1.4% vs. Prev. 1.3%: Cut 2020 inflation forecast. Downgrades due to a fall in household real disposable income stemming from the slowdown in employment growth. Bundesbank notes supportive fiscal policy alongside highly accomodative monetary policy will provide further support. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Turkey is "very close" to signing a deal for the second batch of Russian-made S-400 missile system, deal could be signed before April, according to the Defence Industry Chief

US Special Envoy for Afghanistan said they will be taking a brief pause from talks with the Taliban following the attack on an American base earlier this week. (Newswires)

EU leaders agreed to extend economic sanction on Russia regarding Ukraine, according to diplomatic sources. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BBC’s Katya Adler tweeted that EU leaders will formally welcome the result assuming it is a Tory majority and will call for speedy ratification of the Brexit deal in Parliament, while they will underline the ambition for a broad comprehensive EU/UK trade deal. However, she added that Brussels does not believe an ambitious trade deal is possible to be negotiated and ratified by December next year as PM Johnson claims, with the only possibility in the short time said to be a quick and dirty free trade deal on EU terms. (Twitter/BBC)

ECB's de Guindos says the slowdown in the Euro Area has bottomed out as a disorderly Brexit and trade wars between China and the US are yet to materialise, calls for structural reforms and fiscal policy in Europe to take over from monetary policy. (Newswires)

ECB's Holzmann (hawk) when asked about the ECB's inflation target should be lowered, says there are many counter arguments, no discussions within the ECB GC on inflation yet. (Newswires) 

EQUITIES

European bourses are boosted in early trade [Eurostoxx 50 +1.40%] with upside seen across the board on the back of positive US-China trade developments, coupled with tailwinds from the landslide victory by the market-friendly Conservatives in the UK General Election. UK’s FTSE 100 (1.8%) initially lagged its peers amid FX dynamics as Sterling soared in light of last night’s election exit polls. The index then recovered and now outperforms the European equity sphere as Sterling gives up some gains and large-cap election/Brexit sensitive domestic stocks receive impetus. Banking names such as RBS (+11.1%), Barclays (+9.0%), Lloyds (+8.0%) and homebuilders including Taylor Whimpey (+13.3%), Persimmon (+11.6%) and Barratt Developments (+10.5%) all jumped to the top of the index amid more certainty surrounding Brexit under a Tory government. Meanwhile, UK utility companies (SSE +9.5%, Centrica +8.5%) join the top ranks amid dwindled prospects of privatisation under the Conservatives, whilst BT (+8.0%) similarly benefits as Labour previously noted it wanted to nationalise the Co.  Sectors are all in the green with some underperformance seen across defensives, whilst substantial outperformance is experienced in financials, utilities and consumer discretionary amid the aforementioned movers. Outside of the UK, other notable movers include Delivery Hero (+15.5%) whose shares spiked higher amid source reports that the Co. are reportedly approaching an agreement to purchase Woowa in a potential USD 4bln deal. Airbus (AIR FP) trades higher after Qantas airways selected the Co. as its preferred supplier over Boeing. PSA (+3.1%) shares are supported amid speculation that it may sign its merger with Fiat Chrysler (+2.0%).  Elsewhere, SAP (+1.8%) shares are buoyed by the overall risk sentiment and sub-par guidance from rival Oracle (-1.9% pre-market). On the flip side, Henkel (-3.3%) receives a double whammy from a guidance cut and a broker downgrade.

 

FX

GBP - Sterling has come off the boil, but still bubbling on the back of Thursday’s UK GE that culminated in a clear win for the Conservative Party and hands PM Johnson a convincing majority to get Brexit done, in his very own words. The Pound rebounded after exit polls confounded pre-vote surveys suggesting a much closer contest between the Tories and main protagonist Labour, with Cable peaking just above 1.3500 and Eur/Gbp breaching 0.8300 at one stage. However, some of the euphoria and relief has subsequently waned and the former probed sub-1.3400 territory before returning to the big figure where the heftier of 2 large option expiries reside (1.4 bn compared to 1 bn at 1.3450).

EUR/NZD/CHF/CAD/AUD - All firmer against the Greenback that has lost more ground almost across the board, initially on dovish FOMC vibes then US-China Phase 1 and tariff impulses before Sterling’s election exertions pushed the DXY over the edge (through 97.000 and now meandering between 96.922-712). The single currency has recouped all and more of its post-ECB presser losses and hurdled key chart resistance in the form of the 200 DMA (1.1154), but stopped just short of 1.1200 in contrast to the Kiwi that has now cleared 0.6600 and recouped some declines relative to the Aussie. Indeed, Aud/Nzd has pulled back towards 1.0450 as Aud/Usd pivots 0.6925 and could be hampered by large option expiries rolling off between 0.6885-0.6900 (1.6 bn). Elsewhere, the Franc has bounced within 0.9808-62 parameters and Loonie likewise in a 1.3151-86 band, with the latter also benefiting from positive USMCA developments.

JPY - The lone G10 loser on further safe-haven unwinding rather than a bleak Japanese Tankan it seems, as Usd/Jpy leaps from just below 109.00 and above 109.50.

EM - The Yuan has given up some gains vs the Dollar, but crucially or interestingly the Cnh is holding between 6.9850-9275 even though the PBoC fixed the Usd/Cny midpoint at 7.0000+. content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European bourses are boosted in early trade [Eurostoxx 50 +1.40%] with upside seen across the board on the back of positive US-China trade developments, coupled with tailwinds from the landslide victory by the market-friendly Conservatives in the UK General Election. UK’s FTSE 100 (1.8%) initially lagged its peers amid FX dynamics as Sterling soared in light of last night’s election exit polls. The index then recovered and now outperforms the European equity sphere as Sterling gives up some gains and large-cap election/Brexit sensitive domestic stocks receive impetus. Banking names such as RBS (+11.1%), Barclays (+9.0%), Lloyds (+8.0%) and homebuilders including Taylor Whimpey (+13.3%), Persimmon (+11.6%) and Barratt Developments (+10.5%) all jumped to the top of the index amid more certainty surrounding Brexit under a Tory government. Meanwhile, UK utility companies (SSE +9.5%, Centrica +8.5%) join the top ranks amid dwindled prospects of privatisation under the Conservatives, whilst BT (+8.0%) similarly benefits as Labour previously noted it wanted to nationalise the Co.  Sectors are all in the green with some underperformance seen across defensives, whilst substantial outperformance is experienced in financials, utilities and consumer discretionary amid the aforementioned movers. Outside of the UK, other notable movers include Delivery Hero (+15.5%) whose shares spiked higher amid source reports that the Co. are reportedly approaching an agreement to purchase Woowa in a potential USD 4bln deal. Airbus (AIR FP) trades higher after Qantas airways selected the Co. as its preferred supplier over Boeing. PSA (+3.1%) shares are supported amid speculation that it may sign its merger with Fiat Chrysler (+2.0%).  Elsewhere, SAP (+1.8%) shares are buoyed by the overall risk sentiment and sub-par guidance from rival Oracle (-1.9% pre-market). On the flip side, Henkel (-3.3%) receives a double whammy from a guidance cut and a broker downgrade.

FX

GBP - Sterling has come off the boil, but still bubbling on the back of Thursday’s UK GE that culminated in a clear win for the Conservative Party and hands PM Johnson a convincing majority to get Brexit done, in his very own words. The Pound rebounded after exit polls confounded pre-vote surveys suggesting a much closer contest between the Tories and main protagonist Labour, with Cable peaking just above 1.3500 and Eur/Gbp breaching 0.8300 at one stage. However, some of the euphoria and relief has subsequently waned and the former probed sub-1.3400 territory before returning to the big figure where the heftier of 2 large option expiries reside (1.4 bn compared to 1 bn at 1.3450).

EUR/NZD/CHF/CAD/AUD - All firmer against the Greenback that has lost more ground almost across the board, initially on dovish FOMC vibes then US-China Phase 1 and tariff impulses before Sterling’s election exertions pushed the DXY over the edge (through 97.000 and now meandering between 96.922-712). The single currency has recouped all and more of its post-ECB presser losses and hurdled key chart resistance in the form of the 200 DMA (1.1154), but stopped just short of 1.1200 in contrast to the Kiwi that has now cleared 0.6600 and recouped some declines relative to the Aussie. Indeed, Aud/Nzd has pulled back towards 1.0450 as Aud/Usd pivots 0.6925 and could be hampered by large option expiries rolling off between 0.6885-0.6900 (1.6 bn). Elsewhere, the Franc has bounced within 0.9808-62 parameters and Loonie likewise in a 1.3151-86 band, with the latter also benefiting from positive USMCA developments.

JPY - The lone G10 loser on further safe-haven unwinding rather than a bleak Japanese Tankan it seems, as Usd/Jpy leaps from just below 109.00 and above 109.50.

EM - The Yuan has given up some gains vs the Dollar, but crucially or interestingly the Cnh is holding between 6.9850-9275 even though the PBoC fixed the Usd/Cny midpoint at 7.0000+. Similarly, the Lira remains firm and over 5.8000 despite Turkey’s Defence Ministry declaring that the order for a 2nd Russian S-400 missile system consignment could be struck soon. Elsewhere, the Rouble has largely taken the expected 25 bp CBR rate cut in stride and is still on track to extend its winning run beyond 62.5000.

FIXED INCOME

It remains far too early to tell or premature given the fact that US Treasuries are holding close to their overnight session recovery highs, but the core EU benchmarks may have petered out after extending rebounds to 171.54 (Bunds) and 131.05 (Gilts) and nearly closed technical holes in the process. Nevertheless, the respective 10 year futures are well off intraday/fresh contract lows (170.75 and 130.45) awaiting the return of US peers and some decent data to end a hectic week plus a speech from Fed’s Williams.

COMMODITIES

Little to report thus far in the commodity space, with WTI and Brent futures advances amid the broad risk appetite in the market which emanated from the positive US-China trade headlines and the fallout from the UK General Election. The benchmarks have surpassed 60/bbl and 65/bbl respectively, with the former dipping back below. Eyes will remain on the official announcement of the trade deal from the US side and any comments from the China side confirming whether the two sides struck a deal – sources however noted that China thinks a USD 50bln purchase of ag good is a “hard target”, according to CNBC’s Yoon. Elsewhere, gold prices remain relatively flat downside from safe-haven outflow is countered by a weaker Buck. The yellow metal hovers in a narrow intraday range around USD 1470/oz. Similarly, copper remains flat but above USD 2.75/lb following seven straight sessions of gains.

13th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

UK ELECTION

Conservatives have significantly surpassed the required 326 seats for a majority, currently on 360 seats with a handful of results left. The cable reaction was largely on the exit poll which moved from mid-1.31 mark to 1.3514; its highest since June 2018. Support for GBP stemmed from the implications for the Brexit process given that Johnson stated that all Conservative candidates had agreed to approve the withdrawal agreement in the HoC, the passage of the bill is all but certain (date tbc).

Currently: Cable is currently around the 1.3450+ mark; FTSE 100 Dec’19 futures are at 7308, +21 points. (For reference, the Dax Dec’19 future and EuroStoxx 50 Dec’19 future are significantly outperforming the FTSE 100); the discrepancy is likely due to a number of factors with bourses broadly strengthening on the US-China news flow (see below) while the FTSE 100 future is hampered by the strength of GBP; individual movers may be more interesting as Co’s which were targets for Labour nationalisation (e.g. National Grid (NG/ LN) and BT (BT/A LN)) may see some upside on the relief from their perspective at Labour’s losses. On the other side, upside may be seen in UK banking Names such as (RBS LN), Lloyds (LLOY LN) and Barclays (BARC LN) as well as housebuilders for instance Redrow (RDW LN) and Barratt Development (BDEV LN).

US-CHINA TRADE

China and the US have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the tariffs that were due to come into effect on December 15th according to sources which added that China has agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020, while other source reports also stated the US will announce the trade deal today. However, China leaders are yet to accept the deal (referring to the 'big deal' US President Trump tweeted about) a number of issues: USD 50bln purchases is a hard target, other trade partners complaining at a reallocation who could challenge the WTO., CNBC's Yoon citing sources.

ASIA

A broad heightened appetite for risk was seen overnight with the Asia-Pac majors bolstered and US equity futures extending on Wall St’s fresh record levels as markets reacted to reports that US and China have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the December 15th tariffs, while China is said to have agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020. In addition, focus was dominated by the UK election results in which PM Johnson’s Conservatives are on course for an overwhelming 86-seat majority according to exit polls. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.6%) were lifted with financials after banking regulator APRA advised ADIs it will delay finalizing consultation on implementation of product responsibility requirements until H1 next year but with hefty losses in gold miners restricting gains for the index, while the Japanese benchmark broke through the 24k milestone to print its highest since October 2018 with a somewhat disappointing Tankan survey doing little to contain the rally. Hang Seng (+2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) were also buoyed on the flurry of positive trade rhetoric as aside from the source reports of an agreement being reached in principle, there had also been optimistic comments from US President Trump regarding a trade deal and WSJ initially noted US negotiators offered to cut existing tariff rates by up to 50% although no official announcement has been made yet from either side.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • The result of the UK election exit poll overwhelmingly pointed towards a Conservative majority with a total of 368 seats vs. Labour 191 - Conservatives managed to cross the 326-seat threshold just before 0500GMT
  • GBP immediately saw strength following the election exit poll with GBP/USD eclipsing 1.3500 to the upside from mid-1.3100 area
  • China and the US have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the tariffs that were due to come into effect on December 15th according to sources
  • Further sources noted that there will be a small reduction in tariffs on some Chinese goods as a gesture of good will, while Phase Two of the negotiations will begin after 2020 elections
  • Asia-Pac majors were bolstered overnight, and US equity futures extended on Wall St’s fresh record levels
  • In FX, DXY gave up the 97.000 level on GBP strength, EUR/GBP fell to its weakest since mid-2016
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Import/Export Prices & Retail Sales, Fed’s Williams & ECB’s de Guindos

 

UK ELECTION

The result of the UK election exit poll overwhelmingly pointed towards a Conservative majority with a total of 368 seats vs. Labour 191, presenting the Conservatives with an expected majority of 86. Even with a margin of error of around 15 seats, this stood the Conservatives well clear of the 326 required to govern. In an immediate reaction GBP saw strength across the board with GBP/USD jumping from around the mid 1.31 level to 1.3514; the highest since June 2018. Support for GBP stemmed from the implications for the Brexit process given that Johnson stated that all Conservative candidates had agreed to approve the withdrawal agreement in the HoC, the passage of the bill is all but certain (date tbc).

As the results of individual seats were announced, the findings of the exit poll appeared to be vindicated with Labour broadly either seeing their majority in key seats dwindle or change hands with the Conservatives. As such, the market reaction during the announcement was relatively limited with the Conservatives managing to cross the 326-seat threshold just before 0500GMT; the final result and extent of the majority is yet to be confirmed.

US President Trump congratulates UK PM Johnson on winning the UK election, adds that UK and US are now free for a "massive new trade deal" post-Brexit, "This has the potential to be far bigger and more lucrative than any deal that could be made with EU". (Twitter)

What lies ahead? As we mentioned in our commentary, with the passage of the Withdrawal Agreement almost a given, focus will at some stage turn towards the transition period with the EU which is due to expire in December 2020. A decision on whether to extend this (end of December 2022 is the limit of any extension) is due at the end of June. However, Johnson has backed himself into a corner by stating he would not extend the transition period and therefore in theory, the possibility of a cliff-edge exit is still live. When this becomes the source of focus for the market is yet to be seen, however, the decision over whether to extend or not will likely be set for a much rougher ride than the passage of the WA. From a European perspective, BBC’s Adler has already reported that “Brussels does not believe an ambitious trade deal is possible to be negotiated and ratified by December next year as PM Johnson claims, with the only possibility in the short time said to be a quick and dirty free trade deal on EU terms”

 

TRADE

China and the US have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the tariffs that were due to come into effect on December 15th according to sources which added that China has agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020, while other source reports also stated the US will announce the trade deal today. (Newswires)

Fox Business' Lawrence tweeted that a source stated the December 15th tariffs will not go forward and there will be a small reduction in tariffs on some Chinese goods as a gesture of good will, while Phase Two of the negotiations will begin after 2020 elections.  Furthermore, the source said a signing ceremony will not happen with President Xi and there will be a rollout of the agreement by the White House Friday, while the Chinese have requested that the language of the never be made public. (Twitter)

China leaders are yet to accept the deal (referring to the 'big deal' US President Trump tweeted about) a number of issues: USD 50bln purchases is a hard target, other trade partners complaining at a reallocation who could challenge the WTO., CNBC's Yoon citing sources. (Twitter)

Certain US lawmakers urged US Secretary of State Pompeo and US Commerce Secretary Ross to sanction China related to its actions in Xinjiang, while there had also been separate comments from Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi that US actions have caused serious damage to the hard-won mutual trust between China and US. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

A broad heightened appetite for risk was seen overnight with the Asia-Pac majors bolstered and US equity futures extending on Wall St’s fresh record levels as markets reacted to reports that US and China have struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the December 15th tariffs, while China is said to have agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020. In addition, focus was dominated by the UK election results in which PM Johnson’s Conservatives are on course for an overwhelming 86-seat majority according to exit polls. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.6%) were lifted with financials after banking regulator APRA advised ADIs it will delay finalizing consultation on implementation of product responsibility requirements until H1 next year but with hefty losses in gold miners restricting gains for the index, while the Japanese benchmark broke through the 24k milestone to print its highest since October 2018 with a somewhat disappointing Tankan survey doing little to contain the rally. Hang Seng (+2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) were also buoyed on the flurry of positive trade rhetoric as aside from the source reports of an agreement being reached in principle, there had also been optimistic comments from US President Trump regarding a trade deal and WSJ initially noted US negotiators offered to cut existing tariff rates by up to 50% although no official announcement has been made yet from either side. Finally, 10yr JGBs retraced some of the prior day’s losses which had been the by-product of the dramatically improved trade climate, with the rebound also helped by the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral weekly position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0156 vs. Exp. 7.0139 (Prev. 7.0253)

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Index (Q4) 0 vs. Exp. 2 (Prev. 5); lowest since March 2013. (Newswires) Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Outlook (Q4) 0 vs. Exp. 3 (Prev. 2) Japanese Tankan Large Non-Manufacturing Index (Q4) 20 vs. Exp. 16 (Prev. 21) Japanese Tankan Large All Industry Capex (Q4) 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.6%)

 

UK/EU

BBC’s Katya Adler tweeted that EU leaders will formally welcome the result assuming it is a Tory majority and will call for speedy ratification of the Brexit deal in Parliament, while they will underline the ambition for a broad comprehensive EU/UK trade deal. However, she added that Brussels does not believe an ambitious trade deal is possible to be negotiated and ratified by December next year as PM Johnson claims, with the only possibility in the short time said to be a quick and dirty free trade deal on EU terms. (Twitter/BBC) FX

In FX market, currencies have been solely occupied by the UK election in which GBP/USD rallied to its highest since June 2016 to test the 1.3500 handle following the exit polls which showed Conservatives were on course for a considerable victory of 368 seats vs. Labour at 191 seats, and well over the 326 needed for an absolute majority even when taking into account the margin of error of around 15 seats. The strength in GBP subsequently pressured EUR/GBP to its weakest since mid-2016 and also dragged the DXY firmly below the 97.00 level which the greenback’s major counterparts were quick to take advantage of including EUR/USD which was propped up to just short of resistance at 1.1200, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD also briefly built upon their mild US-China trade inspired gains. Elsewhere, the broad appetite for risk spurred outflows from safe havens JPY and CHF, while CNH strengthened to below the 7.0000 level against the greenback amid the plethora of trade optimism.

BoC Governor Poloz said we don't put a lot of weight on individual data points especially labour data but suggested that the overall trend has been positive, while he suggested they would look at other indicators not just jobs as the labour market tends to lag when asked about an insurance cut if jobs data falls for a third month. Furthermore, Poloz added the bank is seeing a bottoming out of most indicators in the global economy. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Price action across commodities was mostly uneventful as the complex took a back seat to the equity and FX markets with focus overnight centred on the UK election results. Nonetheless, WTI crude futures still eked mild gains as markets also digested source reports that US and China have reached a trade agreement to avert the December 15th tariffs and reduce some of the tariffs already in place which could be announced later today, but with gains capped on some mild unwinding of geopolitical risk premium as Saudi Arabia is said to be looking to ease tensions with Iran and with price action stuck around USD 59.50/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold remained lacklustre following the prior day’s volatility where the precious metal wiped out initial gains as risk appetite was buoyed by the encouraging US-China trade headlines, while copper prices also reflected the broad optimism and recently notched a 7-month high.

Australia Port Hedland iron ore exports 43.3mln tons vs. Prev. 42.0mln tons. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi Arabia is looking to ease tensions with Iran as the Kingdom grows more worried about conflict risks. (WSJ)

US Special Envoy for Afghanistan said they will be taking a brief pause from talks with the Taliban following the attack on an American base earlier this week. (Newswires)

EU leaders agreed to extend economic sanction on Russia regarding Ukraine, according to diplomatic sources. (Newswires)

 

US 

The TPLEX sold off sharply on Trump’s tweet of a “big deal” in China, in addition to the WSJ reporting existing tariffs would be slashed, as part of a cross-asset risk on move, although saw a late session leg lower on reports a Phase One deal was ready to be signed off on, with Trump’s signature being awaited on, although participants are still waiting for absolute confirmation of a deal and that Sunday’s tariffs will be delayed. The attractive yields brought stellar demand to the US 30-year bond reopening auction, with a high yield of 2.307%, the auction was covered 2.46x (firmly above the average 2.23x), stopping through the WI by 2.1bps, a rare occurrence in the long bond. The takedown was just as promising, with dealers taking just 15.5%, 10ppts beneath the average, seeing both directs and indirects take above average; the auction saw a fleeting bid in the 30-year bond as the wider risk appetite prevailed. US T-note (H0) futures settle 28+ ticks lower at 128-12+.

NY Fed said its T-Bill purchases will remain at USD 60bln for the next month and it is to increase its overnight offering to USD 150bln (Prev. 120bln) on December 31st and January 2nd. The Fed also set 10 term repo operations over the next month, starting with a 32-day auction on Monday 16th whilst increasing the limit to USD 50bln from USD 25bln. (Newswires)

US House Appropriations Chair Lowey said a deal has been reached to avert the US government shutdown. (Newswires)

subject: UK ELECTION ROLLING UPDATE: UK election polls continue to remain in-fitting with the exit poll with underpeformance by Labour relative to Conservatives, with Labour's majority in typical safe seats dwindling and losing seats to the Conservatives elsewhere
content:
• The initial trend has saw Labour's lead shrink in some of the first seats to report, whilst the Conservatives hold Swindon North and gain Blyth Valley
  • Thereafter, it much of the same with Labour's margin of victory diminishing and Conservatives holding on to existing seats such as Nuneaton and Broxbourne
  • Conservatives then manged to take Workington from Labour with the Conservatives getting 49.3% (+7.6%) vs. Labour 39.2% (-11.9%); this was seen as a key bellwether seat for the UK electorate. This was shortly followed by the Conservatives taking Darlington and Wrexham (Labour since 1922) from Labour.
  • Initial results in Scotland showed an equally bleak picture for Labour with SNP gaining Rutherglen and Hamilton West from Labour.
  • Elsewhere, performance in Wales in the early stages appeared to be of concern with Labour after losing Vale of Clwyd to the Conservatives.
  • Labour gained Putney from the Conservatives. However, this didn't appear to be enough to turn the tide of the overall Conservative gains.
  • Apporaching 0200GMT, results came in thick and fast. Despite some interesting individual results, there was very little to suggest that the findings of the exit poll were incorrect.
  • At 0221GMT Britain Elects highlighted that the Labour majority has fallen in almost every seat declared so far (91/650)
  • At 0230GMT Latest UK Election count, 102 out of 650 counted, Conservatives 45 seats, Labour 45 seats
  • Iain Duncan Smith held Chingford for the Conservatives, avoiding the potential swing to Labour that some had been looking for.
  • Conservatives take Stockton South (50.7% vs. Labour 41.1%); this seat is seen as generally following the national swing.
  • The trend of Labour losses continued in the Midlands with the party losing Wolverhampton North East to the Conservatives in what appears to be a Brexit vote (leave seat)
  • Chuka Umunna faces defeat as Conservatives win Cities of London and Westminster.
  • Leader of the DUP Nigel Dodds loses his seat in Belfast to Sinn Fein
  • 0300GMT: Latest UK Election count, 195 out of 650 counted, Conservatives 90 seats, Labour 78 seats
  • 0300GMT: BBC forecasts Conservatives to win 357 seats and Labour to win 201 seats (Exit poll had projected 368 vs. 191)
  • Conservatives lose Richmond to the Liberal Democrats, however, Conservative Brexit Secretary Raab holds his seat in Esher and Walton
  • Leader of the opposition Corbyn keeps his seat in Islington North as expected. However, he will not lead the party in the future election but will not step down immediately.
  • 0330GMT: Latest UK Election count, 306 out of 650 counted, Conservatives 156 seats, Labour 108 seats
  • PM Johnson retains his seat in Uxbridge and Ruslip South as expected and widens his majority.
  • Lib Dem Leader Swinson loses her sat in Dunbartonshire East
  • BBC forecasts Conservatives to win 365 seats and Labour to win 196 seats (Exit poll had projected 368 vs. 191)
  • 0400GMT: Latest UK Election count, 306 out of 650 counted, Conservatives 215 seats, Labour 143 seats
  • 0430GMT: Latest UK Election count, 515 out of 650 counted, Conservatives 268 seats, Labour 181 seats
  • BBC forecasts Conservatives to win 362 seats and Labour to win 199 seats (Exit poll had projected 368 vs. 191)
  • The Conservatives have won 326 seats so far, presenting them with an outright majority in the House of Commons, according to ITV

content:

Other News - China looks to set an economic growth target of around 6% for 2020 which is down from this year's goal of 6.0% - 6.5% as the trade war with the US continues to weigh on the country, according to sources. (Nikkei) 

Trade

US and China have reportedly struck an agreement on some tariff reductions and a delay to the tariffs that were due to come into effect on December 15th, with China said to have agreed to purchases of USD 50bln in agricultural goods in 2020, according to sources. (Newswires)

This followed reports which noted negotiators from both sides have reached the terms of a Phase one deal, while US President Trump had also suggested the US was getting very close to a big deal with China and that both US and China want it. (Newswires)

US negotiators reportedly offered to cut existing tariff rates by up to 50% on USD 360bln of Chinese imports and offer to cancel new China tariffs set to take effect on Dec. 15, according to sources. (WSJ)
